goals.question: What is the trend of the number of incidents reported during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Line chart of the number of incidents reported over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the overall pattern of the incidents reported during the LA riots and identify any spikes or dips in the number of incidents.

goals.question: What is the distribution of the type of incidents reported during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of the count of each type of incident
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the most common types of incidents reported during the LA riots and identify any outliers or unusual patterns.

goals.question: What is the relationship between the number of incidents reported and the location of the incident?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of the number of incidents reported by location
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any areas that were more prone to incidents during the LA riots and identify any potential hotspots.

goals.question: What is the distribution of the severity of the incidents reported during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Histogram of the severity of incidents
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the severity of the incidents reported during the LA riots and identify any outliers or unusual patterns.

goals.question: What is the relationship between the number of incidents reported and the time of day?
goals.visualization: Line chart of the number of incidents reported by time of day
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any specific times of day when incidents were more likely to occur during the LA riots and identify any potential patterns.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]

# Line chart of the number of incidents reported over time
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.lineplot(x="date", y="incidents", data=data, color='blue')

# Set chart title
plt.title("What is the trend of the number of incidents reported during the LA riots?", wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show chart
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Plot bar chart of count of each type of incident
sns.countplot(x='Incident Type', data=data)
plt.title('What is the distribution of the type of incidents reported during the LA riots?')
plt.xlabel('Incident Type')
plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Aggregate data by location
location_data = data.groupby(['location']).size().reset_index(name='count')

# Plot scatter plot
sns.scatterplot(x='location', y='count', data=location_data)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the relationship between the number of incidents reported and the location of the incident?', wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=90)

# Return plot object
return plt
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Plot histogram
sns.histplot(data=data, x='severity', kde=True, color='blue')
plt.axvline(x=data['severity'].median(), color='red', linestyle='--', label='Median Severity: {:.2f}'.format(data['severity'].median()))
plt.legend()
plt.title('What is the distribution of the severity of the incidents reported during the LA riots?')
plt.xlabel('Severity')
plt.ylabel('Count')

plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]

# Extract hour from date
data['hour'] = data['date'].dt.hour

# Group by hour and count incidents
incidents_by_hour = data.groupby('hour')['incident_num'].count().reset_index()

# Plot line chart
sns.lineplot(x='hour', y='incident_num', data=incidents_by_hour)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the relationship between the number of incidents reported and the time of day?', wrap=True)

# Set x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Hour of Day')

# Set y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Number of Incidents')

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

# Load data

# Convert date fields to date types

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]
